description: One of the UK's leading drama schools, Mountview is also a cultural hub with resident creative arts organisations, rehearsal space, theatres, TV, acting and dance studios, technical workshops, public cafes and a panoramic rooftop bar.

factsheet.heading: Mountview's History
paragraphs: In 1945 a young sailor in war-time Sri Lanka was barred from joining the entertainment corps by his lowly rank. So he created his own troupe, welcoming all comers.

On returning to Britain he continued the amateur group 
naming it after the local telephone dialling area code: Mountview.
Peter Coxhead, the founder, trained at RADA and began coaching drama school hopefuls for their auditions, eventually formalising this training into an acting foundation course.
Full-time three-year acting and production arts diploma courses followed; the purpose was always to train young people for careers in theatre, film, TV and radio.

In 1992 Mountview launched the first three-year vocational musical theatre course in Europe and in 1999 through a validating partnership with University of East Anglia Mountview awarded its first BA (Hons) degrees. In subsequent years postgraduate courses in performance, direction and producing were launched.

After 73 years in north London, much of it in rented accommodation, Mountview had a need to move into its own home. Southwark Council identified a brownfield site next to the Sterling Prize winning Peckham Library and also provided a financial package to allow Mountview to begin construction whilst fundraising for the remainder of the build cost.

Mountview opened in September 2018 and following the completion of a capital fundraising campaign, including a £1m donation from the Mackintosh Foundation, its main theatre, named The Mack, officially opened in 2021 with a production of Les Miserables.

factsheet.heading: The Building
paragraphs: Carl Turner Architects have designed a building which includes a public foyer with two café/bars, 200-seat and 80-seat theatres and a rooftop restaurant/bar with views across the London skyline. Training facilities include 21 studios, music practice rooms, production workshops, meeting rooms, two TV studios and a radio suite. Further spaces include work space, a retail unit and a 195-m2 rehearsal studio for commercial hire.

The building was built on a vacant brown-field which which had once been home to Area 10, a ‘found’ creative space/performing arts space. Before that the site had housed Whitten’s timber yard and, originally, a canal-side warehouse. It was built by the award-winning contractor Gilbert-Ash who recently completed the Stirling Prize winning Liverpool Everyman Theatre.
Mountview's building was shortlisted for the RIBA London and Civic Trust Awards.

factsheet.heading: About Mountview
paragraphs: Mountview has been training actors and production artists for 75 years. In 1992 they became the first provider of specialised musical theatre training in Europe.

Mountview trains students at foundation, undergraduate and postgraduate level as well as running dynamic evening, weekend and holiday short courses for all ages, and outreach programmes with schools and community groups.

Mountview alumni include Olivier Award winners Rebecca Trehearn and Giles Terera, Evening Standard Award winner Tyrone Huntley, Eddie Marsan, Lindsey Coulson, Douglas Henshall, Mina Anwar and directors Michael Longhurst (Artistic Director of the Donmar Warehouse), Ed Hall, Iqbal Khan and Maria Aberg.
